dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A SIMPLE OVERNIGHT BAG. It rests on a mussed bed in a hotel room. An unseen Packer is refilling it for the trip home. A few shirts, socks, underwear.. MACON'S V.O. The Business. Traveler should bring only what fits in a carry-on bag. Checking your luggage is asking for trouble. The Packer carefully adds a clear plastic bag containing a variety of travel-size packets of detergent, shoe polish, antacid, shampoo, etc. MACON'S V.O. Add several travel-size packets of detergent so you won't fall into the hands of unfamiliar laundries. There are very few necessities in this world which do not come in travel-size packets. The Packer lays in a shaving kit. And on top of it a small format guidebook, well-thumbed and annotated, with a cover illustration of an armchair with wines. Above the drawing it reads THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST and below IN_THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES. SOMETHING WIPES THE FRAME and we see that the Packer has laid a gray suit on the bed next to the overnight bag. Now, he reaches in and picks up the trousers. MACON'S V.O. One suit is plenty...if you take along travel-size packets of spot remover. The suit should be medium gray. Gray not only hides the dirt, but is handy for sudden funerals. The Packer takes us back to the overnight bag as he lays in a thick novel entitled MISS MACINTOSH, MY DARLING. MACON'S V.O. Always bring a book as protection against strangers. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON'S V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Magazines don't last and newspapers from elsewhere will remind you you don't belong. But don't take more than one book. It is a common mistake to overestimate one's potential free time and consequently overpack. In travel, as in most of life, less is invariably more. Now the Packer pauses. He holds this last item a long time in his hands. It is a small, framed snapshot of a smiling young Boy. MACON'S V.O. And most importantly, never take along anything on your journey so valuable or dear...that its loss would devastate you. For the first time, we are CLOSE ON the face of the Packer. His name is MACON LEARY. As he looks at the photograph in his hands, his countenance is masked with grief. And in his eyes, much pain. But no tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BEAUTIFUL CLOUDSCAPE -- white, billowing, extravagant. But no blue sky. Because, as a HORRIFIC ROAR suddenly rushes at us, we see an L-1011 burst into sight BELOW US at five hundred miles an hour and immediately dis- appear, and we realize that we are LOOKING DOWN. And as the ROAR FADES into the much more familiar DRONE of a jetliner's cabin -- THE MAIN TITLE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, good.

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All those other books waste my time telling me how to see as much of these cities as possible. Yours are the only ones that tell me what I really want -- how to — see as little. I tell my wife, "Going with the Accidental Tourist is like going in a cocoon."

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, this is very nice to hear.

dialogues.speaker: . MR. LOOMIS

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS

dialogues.speaker: MR. LOOMIS

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Hello, Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hello, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (adjusting the mirror) I appreciate this.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (turns to pull out) I don't mind 2 little rain.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don't know how you can see to drive.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Maybe you should put on your glasses,

dialogues.speaker: SARAH

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We could stop and wait this out. MACON . Sarah, if I felt we were in the slightest danger I'd have pulled over long ago.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (looks at her) . Honey, I'm trying to be.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You just go on your same old way like before. Your little routines and rituals, day after day.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You're not the only one, Sarah. I don't know why you feel it's your loss alone.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well, I just do, sometimes. A wide lake in the center of the highway crashes against the underside of the car. Macon pumps his brakes.

What you did goes on and on forever. You didn't just kill my son, you killed me, you killed my husband. Do you understand what you did?" Then when I'm sure that he does understand, that he feels just terrible... I'm going to open my purse and pull out a gun and shoot him between the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Place of your own. Well. All right. If that's what you really want.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL

dialogues.speaker: . MACON

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.text: Macon! Welcome back! How was the trip? :

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: This is Julian. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.text: Just when do you figure to bring me a manuscript?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I guess I woke you.

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: “The Accidental Tourist in bed." He makes it sound like the title of something.

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Macon looks at it suspiciously -- he doesn't want any more surprises. Finally, he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel sits on the couch in the living room of her cramped row house. She holds the receiver with her chin and shoulder so her hands are free to try on a variety of press-on fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (still doesn't remember) Ah, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: From the vet's? Who got on so good with your dog?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I was just wondering how Edward was. Macon glances over at Edward.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He looks all right to me.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: No problems?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well... he's developed this new symptom. He gets angry if I leave the house. He starts barking and showing his teeth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eo oe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 38 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 22.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He ought to be trained.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, he's four and a half and I suppose --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: That's not too old! Tell you what, maybe I could just come around and discuss it.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, I really don't think --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Or you could come to my place. I'd fix you supper. (silence) Macon? What do you say? Macon looks at the phone, confused.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I think for now I'll just try to manage on my own.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Well, I can understand that. Believe me. I've been through that stage. So what I'll do is, I'll wait for you to get in touch.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes. That would be good. Goodbye. Macon is replacing the phone on its hook as he HEARS:

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I don't want to be pushy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward stands WHIMPERING and shaking at the open door to the basement, peering down into the gloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon is intently strapping the laundry basket we saw earlier to a colorful skateboard -- Ethan's. Despite some glimmer of satisfaction at his creation, Macon looks worse than ever. Things are going downhill. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 22A. CONTINUED: (Al) ° 38 Macon glances up at Edward at the top of the stairs, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: If you want to come down, come. Otherwise go away. But stop that pitiful whimpering. This basement is not haunted. Macon stands to admire his work, pushing it across the floor toward the laundry chute with his foot. .

dialogues.speaker: . MACON
dialogues.text: That ought to do nicely. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Macon positions the rolling laundry basket under the chute, opens the hatch and watches the squared-off stack of laundry drop neatly into the basket. Macon pushes the basket across the basement to the washing machine and puts the laundry inside. He starts the machine; it SHAKES violently and GRUMBLES into operation. He takes a load from the dryer, drops it in the basket and gives it a kick across the floor. It rolls to a stop at the bottom of the stairs. Macon stands where he was, as if transfixed, lost in space. After a long moment, he snaps out of it.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: : (to himself) Buck up. He walks over to the stairs and is about to pick up the dry clothes when his attention is drawn to the WHIMPERING Edward, who, despite his terror, has made his way hesi- tantly down two steps. Macon is a bit cheered by this and puts out his arms encouragingly.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: That's the stuff, Edward. Come on. Nothing to be afraid of here. Edward quakes down two more steps, WHINING, then loses his resolve. Macon moves up a step toward him, arms open.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Don't give up, Edward. We can make it. Come on. We're both going to make Ethan proud. At that instant the washing machine goes out of balance and begins to ROCK WILDLY, emitting a horrendous SCREECH- ING NOISE. Edward's eyes widen. He leaps from his spot into Macon's chest and arms. Macon, looking at the washing machine, takes the clawed legs in his diaphragm and steps back into empty space. One foot lands in the laundry basket, which immediately rolls out from under him. Macon goes down hard. Edward scampers up to the top of the stairs, YELPING wildly, and stands looking back down at -- Macon, in agony, sprawled on the floor, his leg stuck out behind him at an impossible angle. His eyelids flicker as he looks up the stairs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MACON'S POV of Edward at the top of what seems now an endless staircase. The little dog begins to FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking at a large framed portrait on the wall. It is the Leary siblings as children: Macon in the center, his older brothers PORTER and CHARLES on either side, and, perched in the foreground, his sister ROSE. A LITTLE MOVE OF THE CAMERA reveals them now, thirty years older, eating dinner. All four are intently preparing their baked potatoes. They have scooped out the insides and filled the skins with butter. The floury insides are mashed and seasoned separately. Macon's leg is in a cast to his hip. MACON. I don't think anyone else has any idea where I am.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I mean that I've come to stay over here with you for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Does it matter? Macon considers.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Do you think you should tell Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (no) It's nice to be so unconnected. I wish things could stay that way a while.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Why can't they?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, well, you know, someone will call here, Sarah or someone -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Maybe we could just not answer the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What, let it go on ringing? PORTER . Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Not answer it any time?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Most who call me are neighbors. They'll pop over in person if they don't get an answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I won't miss it. Macon looks at Porter, who shakes his head, "no problem."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four siblings sit at an ancient card table playing a card game of their own invention called Vaccination. Macon is the only one not totally concentrated on the cards. His gaze moves from brother to sister to brother with the same interest they lavish on their cards. Something about this makes him a little uneasy. The telephone in the living room RINGS. Nobody seems to notice. Rose lays a king on Porter's queen.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Stinker.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Hypodermic. Rose lays a king on the ace. Charles reacts, WHISTLING -- excited for him, which is not much. Macon smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: You're a real stinker, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (pulls a card from his hand) Disinfectant.  41 42 43 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon's typewriter and work materials are set up here now. : MACON'S V.O. Generally food in England is not as jarring as in other foreign countries. Nice cooked vegetables, things in white sauce... I don't know why some travelers complain about English food. ~ He hears yelling from the front of the house. JULIAN 0O.S. Help! Help! Call off your dog. Macon props himself on his crutches and makes his way to the window, in the front parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MACON'S POV: Edward has someone treed in the giant magnolia to the right of the walk; he's BARKING and popping off. the ground. .

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (somewhere in branches) Call him off, dammit!

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Edward! Stop that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon struggles down the porch steps and hops over to the magnolia. He manages to lean over and grab the leash Edward is trailing. He peers up into the tree.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: This is your employer, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Julian? Julian lowers himself from the magnolia. He has a line of dirt across the front of his light slacks. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 27.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I really hate a man with an obnoxious dog. I don't hate just the dog, I hate the man who owns him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry about this. I thought he was off on a walk with Porter.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: What happened to your leg?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I broke it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Well, I see that, but how?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: It's kind of hard to explain. Julian supports Macon as they climb the steps.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Do you know how late you're running with this guidebook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon leads Julian into the parlor. Julian looks around * with interest. *

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: This is quite a place. *

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: we It was my grandparents’ house. I grew up here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Where's Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Your wife, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh. Um, she and I are... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Macon crosses to the couch and makes a great business of settling himself and arranging his crutches at his side.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: She's got this apartment downtown.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You've split. Macon nods.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Jesus, Macon, what went wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Nothing. It turns out these things can happen for no particular reason. Edward suddenly flies into the hall BARKING furiously. The front door swings open, hitting the radiator. ROSE 0.S. Hush, now. Rose crosses the hall and looks into the parlor. Julian gets to his feet. Charles comes in behind Rose.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Julian Hedge, this is my sister, Rose. And this is my brother, Charles. Neither Rose nor Charles can shake hands; they are hug- ging brown paper bags full of groceries. They greet Julian.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Macon Leary with a sister! And a brother, too. Who'd have guessed it? That Macon Leary had a family just never entered my mind, somehow.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (irritated) I'm right here, Julian. Rose gives Julian a polite, puzzled smile.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. see a family resemblance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You're Macon's publisher. I'm the one who mailed you Macon's chapters.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to send you some more, but first.I have to buy nine-by- twelve envelopes. All we've got left is ten-by-thirteen. It's terrible when things don't fit precisely. They get all out of alignment.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Ah. Julian looks at Rose for a very long moment, fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: We wouldn't want to keep you, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh! No. She smiles at Julian, hoists her groceries higher, and leaves the room. Charles slogs after her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: The Macon Leary Nine-by-Twelve Envelope Crisis.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, Julian, drop it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Really, I had no idea, Macon. I mean, if you'd let me know what was going on in your life... Look. If you want another, I don't know, another month -- Macon gets up and hobbles off toward the sun porch.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, nonsense, what's a missing wife or two, right? Here, let me get what I've typed and you can check it.

dialogues.speaker: ., (CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: 44 45 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 30.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The front door BANGS open again and Edward begins bark- ing at Porter, who marches through toward the kitchen without a glance into the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (to Edward) Monster. Do you know how long I've been looking for you? Julian is looking after him with a bemused smile when Macon drops the manuscript gently in his lap. Macon sits back down on the sofa as Julian begins to read. The telephone begins to RING over and over; no one answers. Julian locks at Macon and raises his eyebrows. But since no one else seems to hear the RINGING, Julian goes back to his reading. MOVING IN on Macon as he watches Julian and remembers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon and Julian, having just met, sit at a small table in the conservative seafood restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Here's my plan. I own this little company called the Businessman's Press. Well, little: I say little. Actually we sell coast to coast. And now I want to put out a guidebook for commercial travelers. We'd call it something catchy, I don't know: Reluctant Tourist... And you're the fellow to write it.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I knew the minute I read your hot dog essay in the Baltimore Sun.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: That was a one time thing. I work in the family business. I'm not really a writer.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I think you are.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: But I hate to travel. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I thought so. So do businessmen. I mean, these folks would rather be home in their living rooms. So you'll be helping them pretend that's where they are. Julian pulls a square of paper from his breast pocket and flattens it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: What do you think? It is an engraving of the winged armchair we know as Macon's logo.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Your logo. Get it?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: While armchair travelers dream of going places, traveling armchairs dream of staying put! I thought we'd use this on the cover.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Ah! But would I actually have to travel myself?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: But just briefly. I don't want too much information. I'm not looking for anything encyclopedic. I'm looking for the opposite of encyclopedic.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh. (pause) What is the opposite?  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon watches as Julian restacks the manuscript pages.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: After this I want to start on New York and the northeast again.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: So soon?

dialogues.speaker: . JULIAN
dialogues.text: It's been three years, Macon. Julian stands up, and, with some difficulty, Macon does too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they reach the front door, Edward blocks it, BARKING

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Edward, stop it. Macon gives one crutch to Julian and bends to grasp Edward's leash. Edward turns and SNARLS at Macon.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Whoa! Edward SNAPS at his leash with an audible CLICK. Then he SNAPS at Macon's hand. Macon steps back and drops the leash. The other crutch CLATTERS to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Macon? Did he get you? Macon looks down at his hand. There are four red puncture marks in the fleshy party. Julian gives him his crutches, keeping one eye on Edward.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have a dog like that. I'd shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He's never done that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I'd call the S.P.C.A. Or the what's-it, dogcatcher. Tell them you want him done away with.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Just go, Julian. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Julian opens the door and slides through it sideways, glancing back at Edward.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: That is not a well dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose stands on a stepstool in front of a towering glass- fronted cupboard, accepting the groceries that Charles and Porter hand up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I need the n's, anything starting with n.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: How about these noodles? N for noodles? P for pasta?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: E for elbow macaroni. You might have passed those up earlier, Porter. - Macon comes hobbling in. Edward follows shyly.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Rose? It seems Edward's given me a little sort of nip. The siblings stop work to examine his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh, Macon!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: How did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: It was an accident, that's all. But I think I need an antiseptic.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You need a tetanus shot, too.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER .
dialogues.text: You need to get rid of that dog. They look at Edward. He grins up at them nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He didn't mean any harm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Takes off your hand at the elbow and he means no harm? You should get rid of him, I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: See, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Why not? .

dialogues.speaker: ' MACON
dialogues.text: Well, see... They wait. Macon looks down at the dog a long moment, remembering--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In_the living room, we're CLOSE ON a jumping Edward. As 4 he retreats, we see the laughing face of Ethan, the dog's wrestling adversary. The dog comes back for another go. In the kitchen, Sarah's legs WIPE PAST Ethan sitting 50 on the floor gently brushing a becalmed Edward. In the backyard, TRACKING WITH a soccer ball as it rolls across the lawn. Edward catches up to it, crazed, and shoulders into the hedge, GROWLING ferociously. Across the yard, Ethan watches delighted, head thrown back, his laughter high and clear, but seeming now to grow EVER MOR DISTANT. He turns TO LOOK AT CAMERA, at what must be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Macon. His siblings watch him with some pain. Now they avert their eyes tactfully, kindly.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I just can't get rid of him. Rose pulls a first-aid kit from the cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Maybe we could send him to obedience school.  53 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 35. INT. /EXT. ENTRANCE HALL - DAY ° 53 Edward is sitting on the floor. His rump wiggles from his desire to stand up. He is looking up expectantly at-- Muriel Pritchett, who stands above him as Macon, on crutches, watches. Muriel makes a CLUCKING sound with her tongue and holds out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: . MURIEL
dialogues.text: Now you kind of cluck your tongue. They get to know a cluck means praise. And when I hold my hand out -- see? That means he has to stay. Edward stays, but a YELP erupts from him every few seconds. Finally, Muriel snaps her fingers over Edward's head. Edward jumps up, BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: (to dog) That was very good. Muriel reaches into her purse and pulls out a long blue leash attached to a choke chain. She slips the choke chain over Edward's head. :

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He's supposed to wear this every minute till he's trained. That way you can yank him back whenever he does something wrong. She takes a step back and points to Edward's rump. Edward stands fast.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Poke him down. Macon props a crutch against the radiator and bends stiffly to jab Edward with one finger. Edward sits. Macon CLUCKS. Then he straightens and backs away, hold- ing out his palm. But instead of staying, Edward rises and follows him. Muriel HISSES between her teeth. Edward shrinks down again.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He doesn't take you seriously. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, I know that.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: A couple of years ago I saw this ad in the paper. Make extra money in your off hours. Place was a dog-training firm that went around to people's houses. Doggie, Do, it was called. Don't you just hate that name? But anyhow, I answered the ad. I told them that to be honest, I didn't like animals but Mr. Quarles, the owner, he told me that was just as well. He told me it was people who got all mushy about them that had the most trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, that makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Who's the lady?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Lady?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: The lady I just saw walking through the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: That's Rose.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Is she your ex-wife? Or what.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: She's my sister.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, your sister!

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: This house belongs to her.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I don't live with anybody either. Macon blinks, trying to follow her thought.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You can release him now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 37.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Release your dog. Macon snaps his fingers and Edward jumps up, YAPPING.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: How about you? What do you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I write travel guides.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Travel guides! Lucky. I love to travel!

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, travel. It's just red tape, mostly. Ticket lines, customs lines... Should Edward be barking that way? Muriel gives Edward a slit-eyed look and he QUIETS.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: If I could go anywhere I'd go to Paris. It sounds so romantic.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Paris is terrible. Everybody's impolite.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Take me with you next time! I could show you the good parts.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (flustered) Well, I have a very limited expense account. I never even took my wife, or, um, my...wife. :

dialogues.speaker: . MURIEL
dialogues.text: I was only teasing. (looks at him) You think I meant it?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, no. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 54 55 38. CONTINUED: (3) . 53° She grows suddenly brisk.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL,
dialogues.text: That will be fourteen forty, including the leash and the choke chain. You have to practice what he's learned, and no one else can practice for you. Macon counts out some bills and all his change.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You can pay me the other four cents tomorrow. Muriel motions for Edward to sit and hands the leash to Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Release him when I'm gone. Macon holds out his palm and stares hard into Edward's eyes, begging him to stay. Edward stays, but he MOANS when he sees Muriel go out the front door, When Macon snaps his fingers, Edward jumps up and attacks the front door. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The siblings are playing Vaccination. Charles lays down. a good card. Rose and Porter, independently, begin to make the dog-training CLUCKING sound of approval. Macon © looks up. Over in the corner, Edward raises his head,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A damp, drippy morning. Muriel and Macon are in rain- coats. Muriel is teaching Edward to "heel." Macon struggles along on his crutches.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: When I was in high school I made nothing but A's. You're surprised at that, aren't you? You think I'm kind of like, not an intellect. I know what you're thinking! You're surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She glances down at Edward. Abruptly, she slaps her hip; her black vinyl raincoat makes a BUCKLING SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: That's the “heel” command. She starts walking. Edward follows uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He's supposed to match his pace to anything. Slow, fast, anything I do. She speeds up and Edward scurries after her. Edward crosses in front of her and Muriel walks right into him, kicking him. When he dawdles, she yanks his leash. Soon Edward is keeping close to Muriel's left side.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I think he's got the hang of it. Now you. Macon attempts to slap his hip without losing his crutche Then he sets off. Edward keeps pulling ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Yank that leash! He knows what he's supposed to do. Don't forget to cluck. Every little minute, you have to praise him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: This is a bit more difficult with crutches.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Hah! I once taught a man who had no legs and only one arm. Macon looks at her sharply, doubtful.

dialogues.speaker: _ MURIEL
dialogues.text: And he had a Great Dane.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You're not in such bad shape. They reach the front of Rose's house.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I have to get going. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That will be five dollars, please, and the four cents you owe me from yesterday. He gives her the money and she stuffs it in her raincoat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Next time; I'll stay longer and talk. That's a promise. Muriel trills her fingers at him, and clicks off toward a car parked down the street -- an aged, gray, boat-like sedan. She slides in and slams the door -- there is a sound like falling beer cans. The engine TWANGS and RATTLES before it takes hold. Macon watches her go. MACON'S V.O. {same guidebook tone) It is an unfortunate fact that even the most conscientious traveler cannot be prepared for every encounter. At such times, one must remain calm and rely upon one's innate common sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon, on crutches, leans down to speak to Rose once more before she drives away.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Are you absolutely clear about this?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (looking around the area) Yes. I know exactly where we are. (holds up note paper) Besides, I have the address right here! I'll be back in one half hour.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Macon, please. I'm just going around the corner. Now, goodbye. She pulls away. Macon watches with concern, then turns to face the old brick mansion which houses the Business- man's Press. He has a thick manila envelope in hand.  58 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Julian finishes glancing without much interest through the material Macon has brought him. His desk is out in the center of the large, tiled entry hall -- he can't stand to be alone -~ and his secretary is off ina back room. Sailing charts and instruments are everywhere. Julian puts down the papers and regards Macon with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: “The Accidental Tourist on Crutches." Macon gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I guess I'll be going. My sister's picking me up as soon as she gets done with her errand.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Rose? She's coming here? I'd like to see her. Macon looks at him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Macon, do me a favor. Couldn't you just once invite me to a family dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: We're really not much for socializing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: It wouldn't have to be fancy. Just whatever you eat normally. What do you eat normally? Or I'll bring the meal myself. You could lock the dog up. And I'll come spend the evening.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (getting up) When my father said that, it always meant "no". Why don't I step outside and wait with you for Rose.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I'd really rather you didn't.: Julian sinks back in his chair, disappointed.  59 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon watches as Muriel stands over Edward, who dances happily around her. Muriel has a gauzy bouffant scarf over her hair. She points at Edward's rump. The dog sits and Muriel picks up his leash.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: How's your little boy? Muriel looks over at Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Wasn't he sick?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Someone at the vet's, when I phoned. They said your little boy was sick. She goes on looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What was it? The flu? It's that time of year, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: How come you phoned?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I wanted to know why Edward wouldn't lie down. She turns her gaze toward Edward.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I tap my foot but he never obeys me. Something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I told you he'd be stubborn about it.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes, but I've been practicing two days now and he's not --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: What do you expect? You think I'm magical or something? Why blame me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 43. CONTINUED: .

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not blaming --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You most certainly are. You tell me something's wrong, you call me on the phone --

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I just-wanted to --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You think it's weird I didn't mention Alexander, don't you? You think I'm some kind of unnatural mother.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What? No, wait a minute --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You're not going to give me another thought, are you, now you know I've got a kid. You're like, "Oh, forget it, no point getting involved in that." As Muriel's voice grows shriller, the hair on Edward's neck begins to stand up. The dog's lip begins to curl and he starts a low GROWL.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You wonder why I didn't tell you about Alexander right off. Well, isn't it obvious? Don't you see what happens when I do? Muriel looks down at the dog and stops speaking. She taps her foot twice, but Edward rises from his sitting position, a distinct hump between his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Down. With a BELLOW, Edward springs at her fate, every tooth bare and gleaming. Muriel instantly raises the leash. . He stops barking and starts making GARGLING SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He's choking. Stop it. It's enough. You're choking him! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Still, she lets him hang. Now Edward's eyes roll back in their sockets. Macon grabs at Muriel's shoulder. Muriel lowers Edward to the floor. He lands in a bone- less heap. Macon crouches at his side.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Edward? Edward? Oh God, he's dead! Edward raises his head and feebly licks his lips.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: See that? When they lick their lips it's a sign they're giving in. Doggie, Do taught me that. Macon stands up, shaking.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Don't you ever, ever do that again.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: In fact, don't even bother coming again. There is a startled silence.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: (tightening scarf) Well, fine. If that's the way you feel, just fine and dandy. She steps neatly around Edward and opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You want a dog you can't handle? Fine with me.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I'd rather a barking dog than a damaged, timid dog.

dialogues.speaker: . MURIEL
dialogues.text: You want a dog that bites all your friends? You want an evil, nasty dog? That kills the whole world? She slips. out the screen door and closes it behind her. Then she looks through the screen directly into Macon's eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Why, yes, I guess you do. From the hall floor, Edward gives a MOAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA IS LOCKED from the previous scene as daylight fades and the porchlight comes on and suddenly Julian, yet another outsider, is at the Leary's screen door and Rose is admitting him. Edward BARKS from behind some nearby door,

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (a little shy) Hello, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (pleased) Hello, Julian. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I've brought some materials for Macon. Just then Macon appears, with Charles close behind.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I hope I'm not interfering with supper.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (eyes him suspiciously) We've finished.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (disappointed; looks at watch) Really? What time do you eat, anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: But we haven't had our coffee. Wouldn't you like some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I'd love some.

dialogues.speaker: . MACON
dialogues.text: It seems a little silly if you haven't eaten. 59 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose leads the group into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: For me, home-brewed coffee is a real treat. All the people in my apartment building eat out, and there's nothing in any of the kitchens but a couple cans of peanuts and some diet soda.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What kind of place is that?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: It's the Calvert Arms -- a singles building. Everybody's single.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh! What an interesting idea.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (gloomily) Well, not really. Sometimes I wish for the old-fashioned way of doing things, with children and old people like normal buildings have.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, of course you do. I'm going - to get you some nice hot coffee. Rose leaves and Julian watches her out of the room. Macon watches him watch, They sit down.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Where is Porter?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: We're not too sure. He went to a hardware store and we think he - got lost.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Good grief, when did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: A little while before supper.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Supper. Oh, you mean today. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He's just running an errand on Howard Street. Not lost in any permanent sense.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: He got lost on Howard Street?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: It's a problem with this family. Directions.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (irritated) Charles.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: What? Macon gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. I'11 go help Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is setting coffee mugs on a silver tray. Edward makes a racket behind the pantry door.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Julian seems very nice.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He's only here because he hopes we'll do something eccentric. I just pray none of us says anything unconventional around hin.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (she picks up the tray) What would we say? We're the most conventional people I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon and Rose return. Julian jumps up and makes to help Rose. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: looks. 48.
” JULIAN What do you do for a living, Charles?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I make bottle caps.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Bottle caps! Is that a fact!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Oh, well, it's not half as exciting as it sounds, really.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: And Rose? Do you work?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. I work at home. I keep house for the boys. Also I take care of a lot of the older neighbors. They need me to repair their plumbing and such.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You repair their plumbing? The telephone RINGS. The Learys stiffen and exchange

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What do you think? It could be Porter.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Mm...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: But he knows we wouldn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes, he'd surely call a neighbor instead.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: On the other hand...

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Do you always give this much thought to your phone calls? That does it. Macon picks up the receiver. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Leary.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Macon? Macon shoots a glance at the others and turns his back to then.

dialogues.speaker: . MACON
dialogues.text: Hello, Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Well, finally. I've been trying to get in touch with you at home.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: (after moment ) I called because I thought we should talk. I was hoping we could meet for supper some night.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. Yes, we could do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hostess seats Macon at a corner table.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: (indicating crutches) I'll take those for you, darlin’.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, they'll be fine here.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: I need to check them up front, sweetheart. It's a rule.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You have a rule about crutches?

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS -
dialogues.text: They might trip the other customers, honeybunch. Sarah appears beside the table. Macon half stands. ” She comes around the table and presses her cheek to his briefly, rather than kissing him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hello, Macon. What happened to your leg?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Hello, Sarah. I had a kind of... fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. They have their food. Sarah barely touches hers. She looks MACON. Sarah, it's been awful living apart. at him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I asked you here for a reason, Macon. We need to spell out the details of our separation.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I think you ought to come home.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It's not possible.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: . Listen. Don't say no before you hear me out. Have you ever considered we might have another baby? Sarah is taken aback. Macon has shocked himself, too.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Why not? We're not too old.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I realize we can't replace Ethan, but -~

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No. Her tone is definitive. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. But it would never work.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: All right, forget that. It was erazy, right? Crazy notion. All I'm saying is...I think we ought to start over.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I am starting over. I'm doing everything I can to start over, but that doesn't mean I want to live the same life twice. (leans toward him) Macon, we really didn't have much left, don't you see. Look who you turned to when you broke your leg: your family! You're closer to them than you ever were to me.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: That's not true. Or rather, maybe it's true in the sense we're blood relations.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yes, blood. Playing that ridiculous card game no one else can fathom. Cruising hardware stores like other people cruise boutiques.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: As other people cruise boutiques. Macon immediately regrets it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Picking apart people's English. Have to have their precious baked potatoes every night. The best house in the world might come on the market, but you can't buy it because you've ordered these address labels for the old house, | one thousand five hundred gummed labels, and you have to-use them up before you move.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: That wasn't me, it was Charles. _ sl. 65. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 52.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yes, but it could have been you. And his wife divorced him for it. I think when your mother abandoned you all in that house with your grandparents -- % oe

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: She didn't "abandon" us. We chose to live with them rather than travel around with -- % eb SARAH . Exactly! You chose your grandparents over your mother because they had everything under control in their world. Nothing wild, nothing... unpredictable like your mother. And look, Macon, there you all are again, back living in that same old house, all together, with no one from the outside to ruffle the feathers. we Oe Macon lays down his fork.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sarah, it's what happened to Ethan that ruined us. Sarah sets an elbow on the table and covers her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: But it doesn't have to. Why, some people, a thing like this brings them closer together. How come we're ietting it tear us apart? Sarah looks up. Her eyes are deep with tears, but they haven't spilled over.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Macon, ever since Ethan died I've had to admit that people are basically bad. Evil, Macon. So evil they would take a twelve-year- . old boy and shoot him through the skull for no reason. I've given up watching the news on TV. There's so much wickedness. Tears are running down her face now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 53.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: There are times when I haven't been sure I could -- Macon, I haven't been sure I could live in this kind of a world anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: It's true what you say about human beings. I'm not trying to argue. But tell me this, Sarah. Why would that cause you to leave me? She crumples up her napkin and dabs at her face.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Because I knew you wouldn't try to argue. You've believed all along they were evil.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, so --

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: This whole last year I felt myself withdrawing from people. Just like you do, Macon -- just as you do, sorry. I felt I was turning into a Leary.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: There are worse disasters than that, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I can't afford it. I live in this apartment you'd hate, all clutter. I've made a whole bunch of new friends, and you wouldn't like them much either, I guess. I'm studying sculpture again. I always did want to be a sculptor, only teaching seemed more sensible. That's how you would think: sensible. You're so quick to be sensible, Macon, that you've given up on just about everything.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What have I given up on?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Everything that might touch you or upset you or disrupt you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65  THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 54.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I'm sitting here with you, Sarah. You don't see me giving up on you. She chooses not to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: When Ethan died, you emptied his closet and his bureau as if you couldn't be rid of him soon enough. You kept offering people his junk in the basement, stilts and sleds and skateboards, and you couldn't understand why they didn't accept them. Macon, I know you loved him but I can't help thinking you didn't love him as much as I did, you're not so torn apart by his going. Macon reacts to that with an infinitesimal flinch. Sarah sees it, but drives on --

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I know you mourned him but there's something so... what-do-you-call, so... muffled about the way you experience things. It's like you're trying to slip through life unchanged.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sarah, I'm not muffled. I... endure. I'm trying to endure, I'm holding steady.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: If you really think that, then you're fooling yourself. You're encased. You're like something in a capsule. Macon, I'm sorry, but it's not by chance you write those silly books telling people how to take trips without a jolt. So they can go to the most wonderful, exotic places and never be touched by them, never feel they've left home! That traveling armchair isn't just your logo -- it's you.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, it's not. It's not. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 66 67 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 55.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a long moment of anguish, tarn by what she's said, Sarah pulls her coat on, making a sloppy job of it. One corner of her collar is tucked inside.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So anyway. This is what I wanted to tell you: I'm having John Albright send you a letter.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Who's John Albright?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: He's an attorney. (she looks at * him a moment ) . I'm sorry if this hurts, Macon. I'm sorry -- She changes her mind about whatever she was going to say. She stands up and walks out. Macon watches her go, then, very carefully, begins to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. The Waitress carries a set of crutches to the waiting Macon. He gets up on them and begins to make his way across the busy dining room. He has to walk nearly doubled, his chin sunk low on his chest and his elbows jutting. His posture perfectly matches his mood. But some of the other Diners are staring; some SNICKER. He passes two churchy OLD LADIES and one of them tugs at his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: OLD LADY
dialogues.text: Sir? Sir? He comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: OLD LADY
dialogues.text: I suspect they may have given you my crutches. . He looks down at the crutches. They are diminutive -- hardly more than child-sized. He stands hanging his head, waiting for someone to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE-UP of the blade of a tiny, purring electric saw as it cuts through the cast on Macon's leg, throwing off bits of plaster and gauze. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 68 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 55A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Macon watches the doctor work we begin to HEAR the slightly disturbing MUSIC which will play into the fol- . Macon's leg emerges dead-white and wrinkled. Macon looks at it as he would a stranger, and as we MOVE IN on his face, we HEAR, competing with the MUSIC, the sound of a HOWLING WIND, which grows stronger as we go to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls up to the curb and Macon gets out, treating his leg gingerly. It is here that the HOWLING WIND blows across the huge plaza. We have not seen the buildings yet, but as Macon limps across the space, he looks up. And up and up. And for the first time we do too, in -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 68A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Could I have a menu, please?

dialogues.text: Menu? Didn't I give you one?

Now he turns’ 75 with a smile to look at Macon, who --
