dialogues.text: Drops the glass of sherry on the floor of the restaurant. There is a FLURRY OF VOICES around him. Macon turns quick ly from the window, his expression anguished, and runs lopsidedly and limping across the room. The MUSIC grows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In_the corridor to the elevators, Macon staggers to a halt, panicked. He can't make the long trip to the ele- vator. He turns to his right, hurries past some phones and pushes into the Men's Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon stumbles into a stall. and stands there, steadying himself against the wall. He presses his fingers against his temples fiercely. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon cracks open the Men's Room door and looks out. No one around. Macon goes to a phone, listens for a tone and begins punching numbers.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (strangled whisper) Please answer...just this once, pick up the phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON the old black wall phone RINGING. There is : terrible BARKING, CLAWING and GROWLING going on just below frame. The phone rings twice before a man's hand » desperately grabs the receiver and pulis it off-camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles has snatched the phone from the kitchen wall and brought it inside here to the safety of the pantry. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He clenches the knob of the door, which is being attacked from outside by Edward. Charles is close to hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes! Leary here!

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Charles?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Macon! WE BEGIN TO INTERCUT Macon and Charles.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Charles, I'm up on top of this building and a sort of...silly thing has happened. Listen: you've got to get me out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You out! What are you talking about? You've got to get me out!

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I'm shut in the pantry. Your dog has me cornered.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, I'm sorry, but... Charles, it's like some kind of illness or attack or something. I don't think I can manage the elevator and --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Macon, do you hear that barking? That's Edward. Edward has me treed, I tell you, and you have to come home this instant.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: But I'm in New York! I'm up on top of this building and I can't get down! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Every time I open the door he comes roaring over and I slam the door and he attacks it, he must have clawed halfway through it by now. : Macon makes himself take a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Charles, could I speak to Rose?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: She's out. Julian came to take her to dinner and --

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Julian?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Isn't that his name?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Julian my boss?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yes, and Edward went into one of his fits. So Rose said "Quick, shut him in the pantry.” So I grabbed his leash and he turned on me and nearly took my hand off. So I shut myself in the pantry instead and Rose must have left by then and Porter's out... Macon places his hand over his heart for a moment; the beating seems wrong.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: If you don't get me out of this I'm going to call for the police to come shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No! Don't do that!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I can't just sit here waiting for him to break through. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He won't break through. You could open the door and walk right past him. Believe me, Charles. Please: I'm up on top of this building and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't know that I'm prone to claustrophobia. (pause) Macon, I'm sorry, but you knew that dog would have to be done away with sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Don't do it! A Man going into the restroom glances in Macon's direction.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (lowering his voice) He was Ethan's.

dialogues.speaker: " CHARLES
dialogues.text: Does that mean he's allowed to tear my throat out?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Charles...let's think this through. I'm going to get you out of there. So don't do anything hasty. Are you listening, Charles? Macon hangs up and takes his wallet from his pocket. He sifts despairingly through the numbers in his wallet. Then he sees the name: Muriel Pritchett. The card is handwritten, even hand-cut, crookedly snipped from a larger piece of paper. He punches the numbers.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hel-lo.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Muriel? It's Macon Leary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel has a magazine on her lap. She sits on a ratty sofa. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Oh! How are you doing? WE BEGIN TO INTERCUT Macon and Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Or, rather... See, the trouble is, Edward's got my brother cornered in the pantry, overreacting -- Charles I mean -- he always overreacts. And here I am on top of this building in New York and I'm having this kind of, um... disturbance, you know? I was looking down at the city --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Edward's in your pantry -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Edward's outside the pantry, barking. My brother says he's going to call the police and tell them to come shoot Edward.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Well, what a dumb fool idea.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes! So I thought if you could go over and get the key from the mailbox --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I'll go right away.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: So good-bye for now, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Wait! But also -- See, I'm up on top of this building. Something has scared the hell out of me.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord, I'd be scared too after I went and saw Towering Inferno.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, no, it's nothing like that, fire or heights -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Did you see Towering Inferno? Boy, after that you couldn't get me past jumping level in any building. JI think people who go up in skyscrapers are just plain brave. I mean if you think about it, Macon, you have to be brave to be standing where you are right now. : This stops Macon cold for several beats.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, well, not so brave as all that.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: No, I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: MACON -
dialogues.text: You're making too much out of it. It's nothing, really.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You just say that because you don't realize what you went through before you stepped into the elevator. See, underneath you said, "Okay, I'll trust it." Why, you ought to be walking around that building so amazed and proud of yourself! Macon gives a small, dry laugh and grips the receiver more tightly.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Now, here's what I'm going to do. I'm going to go get Edward and take him to the Meow-Bow. Then when you get back from your trip, we need to talk about his training. I mean, things just can't go on this way, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, they can't. You're right. They can't.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I mean this is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: See you, then. ‘Bye.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Wait -- Muriel! But she is gone. Macon hangs up. He turns and sees a TEEN COUPLE coming down the corridor from the elevator. The girl's dress is clumsy and touching, her chin hidden by a monstrous orchid. Halfway down the corridor, the couple stops to gaze around at the wondrous surroundings, and at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Hoo! He grabs both the girl's hands and kisses them, then leads her past Macon into the restaurant. Macon watches for a moment -- soothed -- and then follows them inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon watches Muriel as she stands over Edward, who lays squirming on the hall rug. MURIEL . I'll be honest, my baby was not exactly planned for. If you want to know the truth, the baby was the reason we got married. (checks Macon's reaction, then indicates the dog) Now I'm going to turn my back, and you watch how he does. Muriel wanders into the living room. She lifts a vase from a table and examines its underside. She sits on the couch and raises one foot in front of her, turning it admiringly this way and that. Her stocking bags at the ankle; she pulls it up.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Pretty soon he'll lie like that for three hours straight.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Three hours? Isn't that sort of cruel?

dialogues.speaker: . MURIEL
dialogues.text: I thought you promised not to talk like that. ~ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Right. Sorry. Muriel comes back into the entrance hall and directly up to Macon in a way that makes him back away involuntarily. He just misses stepping on Edward.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: My son's name is Alexander. Did I tell you that? Something went wrong while I was carrying him and they had to do a Caesarean and take him out early and I can't ever have any more children. Alexander was so teeny he didn't even look like a human, and he had to stay in an incubator forever, just about, and nearly died. Norman -- that's my ex-husband -- he said, "When's it going to look like other babies?" Norman always called Alexander "it." Edward WHIMPERS. He is just barely lying down -- his haunches braced, his claws digging into the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Maybe you and Alexander should get together some time.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, I, ah....

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He doesn't have enough men in his life. Maybe the three of us could go to a movie. Do you ever go to movies?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I really don't care for movies. They make everything seem so close up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon comes in in his bathrobe with Edward tagging along behind. He turns on the light above the stove and squints at the oven dial. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: One hundred forty degrees... Certain death, What is she thinking? Charles walks in, wearing large, floppy pajamas. He too peers at the oven dial. He sighs and opens the oven door. Both brothers look inside. WHAT THEY SEE: A huge turkey, cooking at very slow heat, looks a little like Macon's leg when it came out of the cast.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Two quarts of stuffing. I heard her say so. Two quarts of teeming, swarming bacteria.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (serious) Is this the Thanksgiving we all die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon comes in. Rose is cheerily serving Charles pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Rose, what exactly is it you're doing to this turkey?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I told you: slow heat. Jam, Charles, or syrup? See, I read an article about slow-cooked beef and I thought, well, if it works with beef it must work with turkey, too. But at the end I'm going to raise the temperature.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You'd have to raise it mighty high.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You'd have to expose it to a nuclear flash.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, you're both just plain wrong. Who's the cook here anyhow?  87 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanksgiving dinner. The table is laden with attractive side dishes. In addition to the Leary brothers, there are two guests -- Julian and MRS. BARRETT, one of their elderly neighbors. They look expectantly toward the kitchen door. Rose enters holding the turkey high on a platter as if in triumph. Odd since the bird looks bad, its breast caved in, its skin dry and dull.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BARRETT
dialogues.text: Ah!

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I just wish my neighbors could see this.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: There may be a little problem here. Rose sets the turkey down and glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Of course, the rest of the meal is excellent. Why, we could fill up on the vegetables alone! In fact I think I'll do that. But the turkey...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: It's pure poison.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: We think it may have been cooked at a slightly inadequate temperature.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: It was not! It's perfectly good.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Barrett, maybe you'd rather Just stick to the side dishes. Mrs. Barrett now looks more closely at the turkey.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BARRETT
dialogues.text: Why, perhaps I will. I don't have much of an appetite anyhow. ” (CONTINUED)  87

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose sits Julian is 67.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh, Macon, how could you do this? My lovely turkey! All that work!

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I think it looks delicious.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Yes, but you don't know about the other times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other times? down, tears glazing her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You don't fool me for an instant. I know why you're doing this. You want to make me look bad in front of Julian.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Julian? distressed. He takes a handkerchief from his pocket but then just holds it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You want to drive him off! You three wasted your chances and now you want me to waste mine, but I won't do it. I can see what's what! Love is what it's all about. And you want to make me miss it!

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, goodness.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You just don't want me to stop cooking for you and taking care of this house. You don't want Julian to fall in love with me.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Do what? Rose scrapes her chair back and runs from the room. Julian sits there with his mouth open. Macon looks at hin.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Don't you dare laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: De you think I ought to go after her?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: But she seems so --

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: She's fine! She's perfectly fine. Now, who wants a baked potato? There is a MURMUR around the table; everyone looks unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BARRETT
dialogues.text: That poor, dear girl. I Feel just awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian? Potato?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I'll take the turkey. Macon is stopped for a moment. He looks at Julian in a new way. And he likes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel and Macon are walking with Edward, training him not to chase cyclists.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Norman couldn't understand why I was all the time at the hospital visiting Alexander. He was in for months. You should have seen our medical bills. Finally I took a job at the hospital. I got a kind of, like a maid's job, emptying trash cans, wet-mopping floors... A biker appears at the end of the street, a Girl with a Baskin-Robbins uniform bunching below her jacket. Edward perks his ears up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Now, act like we expect no trouble. Just go along, go along, don't even look in Edward's direction. The Girl skims by them. Edward sniffs the breeze but marches on,

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Edward, that was wonderful! Muriel just CLUCKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finally did let Alexander come home. Cried like a kitten would cry. And Norman would get this kind of stubborn look whenever I had to do something, go warm a bottle or something. I'd be hanging over the crib watching Alexander fight for air, and Norman would call, "Muriel? Commercial's just about over!" Macon watches her..

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: And then one day Norman's mother came over to help him pack his clothes and he left me. She slows and then comes to a stop. Edward, with a martyred sigh, sits down at her heel.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: All that time Alexander was in the hospital seemed so awful, but now when I look back, I almost miss it. I mean there was something cozy about it. I think about those nurses gossiping at the nurses' station and those rows of little babies sleeping. It was winter and sometimes I'd stand at a window and look out and I'd feel happy to be warm and safe. I'd look down at the emergency room entrance and watch the ambulances coming in. You ever wonder what a Martian might think if he happened to land near an emergency room? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He'd see an ambulance whizzing in and everybody running out to meet it, tearing the doors open, grabbing up the stretcher, scurrying along with it. "Why," he'd say, “what a helpful planet, what kind and helpful creatures." He'd never guess we're not always that way, that we had to, oh, put aside our natural selves to do it. "What a helpful race of beings," a Martian would say. Don't you think so? She looks up at Macon. Macon experiences a sudden twist in his chest. He bends and kisses her, surprising them both. Her fist with the leash in it is caught between them like a stone. Macon draws back.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well... She goes on looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sorry. They turn and walk back toward Rose's in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is knitting Julian a sweater. Macon, a book in his lap, watches her needles flashing.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Actually, have you ever noticed that Julian wears crew necks? ROSE. That doesn't mean he wouldn't wear a V-neck if he had one.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You know, he's younger. I don't know if you realize that.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Two years.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: But he's got a younger, I don't kmow, style of living. Singles apartments and so on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: He's tired of all that. Don't try to spoil this, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, I only want to protect you. It's wrong, you know, what you said at Thanksgiving. Love is not what it's all about. There are all kinds of other issues.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: He ate my turkey and did not get sick. Two big helpings. Macon looks pained. He has no answer to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel is driving her long gray boat of a car. Macon sits beside her. Edward is in back, his ears horizontal with joy as he sticks his head out the window.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I got this car for only two hundred dollars. That's because it needed work. But I took it to Dominick, this boy down the street from where I live. I said, “Dominick, here's the deal. You fix my car up, I let you have the use of it three nights a week and all day Sunday." Wasn't that a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Very inventive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon approaches the big window in front as though sneaking up on someone. He stops and looks. MACON'S POV. Edward is sitting obediently out on the sidewalk. Now Macon's gaze shifts down the sidewalk two car lengths. Muriel is leaning against the fender of her car making faces into a brown plastic compact. She barely glances in Edward's direction. CLOSE ON Macon as he stares at Muriel.  92 93 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon comes out of the grocery store and goes over to pat and CLUCK over Edward.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Give him lots of praise! Muriel leads them next door to a drugstore and motions for Edward to "stay."

dialogues.speaker: . MURIEL
dialogues.text: This time we'll both go in.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Is it safe?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: We'll have to try it sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon and Muriel stroll back to the cosmetics counter. Macon keeps looking toward the front. Muriel stops to try on a lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Too pink. What are you doing for dinner tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Come- and eat at my house. Come on. We'll have fun.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Un...

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Just for dinner, you and me and Alexander. Say six o'clock. Number Sixteen Singleton Street. Know where that is?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I don't believe I'm free then. Muriel looks at him a moment, smoothing lipstick with her lips. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Think it over a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RECEPTIONIST is a gray-haired woman. Muriel sits reading a magazine. Macon raises one of the slats of the venetian blinds to check on Edward sitting on the sidewalk outside. MACON . How old did you say Alexander was?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He's seven. Have you thought?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Have you given any thought to coming to dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh. ‘Well, I could come. If it's only for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: What else would it be for? She smiles up at him and tosses her hair back.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Here he is. ALEXANDER comes out. He is a small, white, sickly boy with a shaved-looking skull. His eyes are magnified behind large spectacles whose clear frames have a pinkish cast. He wears a carefully coordinated shirt-and-slacks set such as only a mother would choose.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Sweetie, this is Macon. Can you say hi? _ Macon holds out his hand. After a moment, Alexander shakes it weakly.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You're pretty young to be at the doctor's without your mother. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He's used to it because he's had to go so often. He's got these allergies.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I see. Muriel takes care of the bill at the counter, with cash.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He's allergic to shellfish, milk, eggs, and most vegetables. Also, dust, pollen and paint, and we think maybe he's allergic to air. Whenever he's outside a long time he gets these bumps on any uncovered parts of his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander rides next to Muriel. Macon sits in back with Edward.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Alexander is subject to asthma, exzema, and nosebleeds. If a bee ever stings him and he hasn't had his shots he could be dead in half an hour. Alexander turns his head slowly and gazes at Macon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon sits alone with a box of good stationery and pen in hand. He has rejected several attempts. Now he tries again -- MACON'S V.0O. Dear Muriel -- He lifts the pen. Finally, he begins to write again. : MACON'S V.O. I am very sorry, but I won't be able to have dinner with you after all. Again he lifts the pen, anguished. After a long moment, he seems inspired and writes -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON'S V.0.
dialogues.text: Something has come up. His face falls -- that's not as inspired as he thought it was. Still, he presses on -- MACON'S V.O. Regretfully, Macon. He lays down the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon is driving through the labyrinth of littered, cracked, dark streets in the south of the city. He turns onto Singleton Street and finds a block of row houses. The bricks of Number 16 have been painted a rubbery maroon. An orange bugproof bulb glows dimly above the front stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Last year, I lost... I experienced a...loss, yes, I lost my... Muriel looks patiently into his face.

dialogues.text: I lost my son. He was just...he went to a hamburger joint and then...someone came, a holdup man, and shot him. I can't go to dinner with people! I can't talk to their little boys! You have to stop asking me. I don't mean to hurt your feelings but I'm just not up to this, do you hear? Muriel's head moves, just barely, almost a nod.

dialogues.text: Every day I tell myself it's time to be getting over this. I know that people expect it of me. But if anything, I'm getting worse. The first year was like a bad dream -- I was clear to his bedroom door in the morning before I remembered he wasn't there to be wakened. But this second year is real. I've stopped going to his door. I've sometimes let a whole day pass by without thinking about him. I believe that Sarah thinks I could have prevented what happened, somehow -- she's so used to my arranging her life. Now I'm far from everyone. I don't have any friends anymore and everyone looks trivial and foolish and not related to me. Macon seems depleted. It has taken all his energy to say this.  100 101 77.

His divorce was awful. He said he didn't think he could ever trust a woman again. He didn't: like going to sleep when a@ woman was in the same room. But bit by bit I changed all that. He relaxed. We started talking about getting married. Then he met an airline stewardess and eloped with her within the week.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: It was like I had, you know, cured him, just so he could elope with another woman. There is a moment of silence. Macon shifts, putting his arm around Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINICK
dialogues.text: Now this here is your paste wax. (holding up a can) You never want to polish a car with anything but paste wax. And here we have a diaper. Macon comes downstairs and collects his jacket from a closet. He and Muriel are going out and Dominick is babysitting. Macon listens too.

Muriel comes downstairs in a flurry, collecting her purse and jacket and keys. She glances at the pair on the sofa, but what finally captures her attention is the look on Macon's face as he watches the other two finish the story --

dialogues.speaker: DOMINICK
dialogues.text: So what you do is, you get yourself these here supplies and a case of good beer and a girl, and you head on out to Loch Raven. dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I don't think Alexander's getting a proper education. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.text: Muriel...marriage is...I don't know... .

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You think you can just drift along like this, day by day, no plans. Maybe tomorrow you'll be here, maybe you won't. Maybe you'll just go on back to Sarah. He looks up at her sharply.

dialogues.speaker: MACON

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Can you do this?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon follows the Police Officers down a series of halls and into the morgue. They lead him to a small body bag on a gurney and open it. .

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes. That is my son. Edward's BARKING gets louder and more excited and we CUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon suddenly hears Edward's BARKING. He gets up and leaves the room.  150 151 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon opens the front door. Julian is standing outside with a file folder in hand. Macon opens the door and lets him in.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Thought I'd bring you the material for Paris. Macon nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian sits down on the couch which is so new it is still covered in cellophane. He puts the folder aside. Each shift of his body makes the cellophane CRACKLE.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (indicates sofabed) Just arrived this morning. Julian nods but doesn't seem to have heard.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Do you think Rose is not coming back?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (carefully) She's worried about the boys. They're eating glop or something.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Those are not boys, Macon. They're men in their forties. I'm afraid she's left me.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, now, you can't be sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: And not even for any reason! Our marriage was working out fine. But she's worn herself a groove or something in that house of hers, and she can't help swerving back into it. . (he looks at Macon) At least, I can't think of any other explanation.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, it sounds about right. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They sit silently for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Why don't you give her a job, Julian?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Job?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Why don't you show her that office of yours. That filing system you never get sorted, the secretary | chewing her gum and forgetting whose appointment is when. Don't you think Rose could take all that in hand?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Well, sure, but --

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Call her up and tell her your business is going to pieces. Ask if she could just come in and get things organized, get things under control. Put it that way. Use those words. Get things under control, tell her. Then sit back and wait. (pause) But of course, what do I know? Julian looks at him intently, his mind racing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: No, you're right.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Now let's see your folder.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (hands it over, distracted) You're absolutely right. Macon opens it and reads the topmost letter.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Look at this! Why do you bother me with this? "I just wanted to appraise you folks of a wonderful little hotel in..." (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A man who says he wants to "appraise" us, do you really suppose he'd know a good hotel when he saw one?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Macon.

dialogues.speaker: . MACON
dialogues.text: The whole damn language has been slaughtered.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Macon, I just want to say this -- I care about that sister of yours more than anything else in the world. It's not just Rose, it's the whole way she lives, that house and those turkey dinners and those evening card games. And I care about you, too, Macon. You're my best friend! At least, I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, why, ah -- Julian gets up. and takes Macon's hand, shaking it more vigorously than Macon is prepared for. He claps Macon on the shoulder and strides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Sarah walks ahead of Macon to the entrance of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How's the fabric look?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah stands squinting at the new sofa bed. Macon stands behind her.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Seems fine to me, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Honestly, Macon. I don't know what's come over you. You used to be downright finicky.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: It's fine, Sarah. It looks very nice. Sarah strips off the cellophane and stands back, arms full of CRACKLING light.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We ought to see how it opens out. Macon pulls at the canvas strap that turns the couch into a bed and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Maybe we should put on the sheets, now that we've got it open. Sarah disappears and then returns with a stack of linens from the front hall. With Macon positioned at the other side of the couch, she floats a sheet above the mattress and then bustles up and down, tucking it in. Macon stops helping and watches her move about.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Let's give the bed a trial run.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (looks up, not understanding) Trial run? But she allows him to take the sheet away and slip her sweat shirt over her head. Languid, lazy and slow, they drop to the new mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon comes out of the bathroom. Sarah, in her slip,. is Standing in front of the bureau, screwing on little gold earrings. They are dressing to go out. Macon chooses a shirt.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Macon. MACON ‘ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You never asked me if I slept with anyone while we were separated. Macon pauses, halfway into one sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Don't you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No. Macon puts on the shirt and begins buttoning the cuffs.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I would think you'd wonder.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, I don't. _ Sarah watches Macon in her mirror for a few beats.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Macon, the trouble with you is 7

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (flaring, surprising them both) Sarah, don't even start! By God, if that doesn't sum up everything that's wrong with being married. "Macon, the trouble with you is --" and "I know you better than you know yourself, Macon --"

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (continuing steadily) The trouble with you is, you think ~ people should stay in their own sealed packages. You don't believe in opening up.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Okay, let's say that that's true. Let's say for now that you do know .what the trouble with me is, that nothing I might feel could surprise you. And that the reason I don't want to hear about this specific thing is that I can't open up. If we agree on all that, can we drop it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Macon takes a tie from the rack in his closet. Sarah watches him for several long beats, then goes back to her makeup. :

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: For your information, I didn't sleep with anyone the whole entire time. . Macon pretends that -he hasn't heard her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane to Paris is crowded as Macon finds his seat. Macon glances up the aisle, where more passengers are arriving. A Japanese Man, a Nun, a Young Girl in braids. A Woman with a little red vanity kit, her hair a dark tent. Muriel. She walks toward him, watching her feet. When she is next to him she raises her eyes and it's clear that she's known all along he was there.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I'm going to France.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: But you can't! The French Couple next to him look at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I'm going to walk along the Seine. Muriel notices the people stacking up behind her and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie is showing in the darkened cabin. Macon makes his way down the aisle, his shaving kit in hand. The lavatories are occupied, so Macon waits. He turns to find Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Muriel, what in --

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You don't own this plane! And you don't own Paris, either. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 3/14/87. 119. CONTINUED: Me 156." Macon presses his lest temple. :

dialogues.text: . MACON” : : I ‘don' t understand any of this. How could you afford the fare?

dialogues.text: There is a KNOCK on the door and, surprisingly, Macon looks relieved. He rushes to the door and opens it. Muriel breezes in, goes over to the window.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Your room is bigger than mine is. I have a better view, though. Just think, we're really in Paris! The bus driver said it might rain but I told him I didn't care. Rain or shine, it's Paris. MACON . How did you know what bus to take?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I brought along your guidebook. She pats her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Want to go for breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, I don't. I can't. You'd better leave, Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. She leaves. Macon goes over to the phone on the bureau and picks up the receiver. It is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lobby telephone is housed in an ancient wooden booth.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is in bed. The call woke her up. We begin to INTERCUT Macon and Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Macon? Macon, where are you? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Nothing's the matter. I just felt like talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What? What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I know it's early and I'm sorry I woke you but I wanted to hear your voice.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: There's some kind of static on the line.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: How's the weather there?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How's who?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: The weather! Is it sunny?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't think it's even light yet.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Will you be gardening today?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Gardening!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well, I hadn't thought. It depends on whether it's sunny, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I wish I were there. I could help you.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You hate to garden! Macon, are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm fine. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How was the flight over?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (moment of panic) Oh, the flight, well, goodness! I guess I was so busy reading I didn't really notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you've got jet lag. We CUT IN CLOSE on Macon here. There's something in his eyes. He seems not so much jet-lagged as, well, at sea.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks blindly down the sidewalk, scribbling in the margins of his guidebook. MACON'S V.0O. It's puzzling how the French are so tender in preparing their food but so rough in serving it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon comes into the room -- footsore, leg muscles aching -- and collapses on his bed. There is a KNOCK at the door He GROANS and rises to open the door. Muriel stands there with her arms full of clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Look. See what-all I bought. She marches in and dumps clothes on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Muriel, have you lost your senses? What must all this have cost?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Nothing! Or next to nothing. I found a place that's like the granddaddy of all garage sales. If you say something's too expensive, they'll bring the price down till it's cheap enough. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw this leather coat I would have killed for but the man wanted ninety francs.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Ninety francs is fifteen dollars or so.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, really? I thought francs and dollars were about the same.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Well, then these things were super bargains. Now let me take these back to my room so we can go eat.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (beat) No, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: What harm would it do to eat supper with me, Macon? I'm someone from home you've run into in Paris! Can't we have a bite together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon and Muriel sit at a table at the Burger King on the Champs-Elysees.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Careful, these aren't the Whoppers you're used to. You'll want to scrape the extra pickle and onion off. She ignores him, takes a bite and makes a satisfied face.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Who's looking after Alexander?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Oh, different people.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What different people? I hope you haven't just parked him, Muriel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 165 166 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 124. CONTINUED: ° 165

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Relax. He's fine. Claire has him in the daytime and then Bernice comes in and cooks supper and any time Claire has a date with the General the twins will keep him or if... The CAMERA IS OUT AT the street now looking back at them as Muriel continues. And Macon listens, with a kind of wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon and Muriel must stand close together in the tiny elevator.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Can I come to your room a while? My TV set only gets snow.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: We'd better say good night.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Can't I just come in and keep you company? .

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: ’ We wouldn't have to do anything. The elevator stops at his floor. He steps out, but turns and holds the door.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Don't you understand my position? I've been married to her forever. I can't change now.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Why is that? All Muriel's makeup has worn off and she looks young and sad.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Good night. He lets the elevator door close.  167 168 169 125.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon can be seen through the window writing in his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: MACON'S V.0,
dialogues.text: Den't fall for prix fixe. It's like a mother saying "Eat, eat" -- all those courses forced on you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon. Macon walks wearily back to his own hotel. He sees Muriel up ahead, arms full of parcels. Before he even thinks, he calls out --

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Muriel! She turns with a big smile and waits for him to catch up. He accepts several of her parcels. They head off together toward the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Macon, could we eat someplace nice today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon and Muriel sit at a table near the windows that front a lovely restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: (studying menu) If I ask them what something is in English, do you think they'll be able to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't have to bother doing that. Just order Salade Nicoise.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Order what?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I thought you said you'd read my guide. Salade Nicoise. It's the one safe dish. I've been all through France eating nothing but, day in and day out.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: That sounds kind of monotonous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, it's not. Some places put green beans in it, some don't.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I think I'll just ask the waiter. She lays her menu aside.

dialogues.speaker: . MURIEL
dialogues.text: Do you suppose they call them French windows in France?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (confused) What? Oh, I really don't have the slightest idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. A pleasant Waiter and Muriel agree on a dinner for her. The Waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: There. Wasn't he nice?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: That was a rare exception. She bats at the hem of her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Durn fringe! I keep thinking something's crawling up my leg. Where you going tomorrow, Macon?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Out of Paris altogether. Tomorrow I start on the other cities.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You're leaving me here alone?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: This is high-speed travel, Muriel. Not fun. I'm waking up at crack of dawn.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Take me anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I can't. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I haven't been sleeping so good. I get bad dreams. Last night I dreamed about Dominick. I dreamed he was mad at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't talk to me. Wouldn't look at me. ‘Turned out he was mad because I wouldn't let him use the car anymore. I said, "Dommie, you're dead. You can't use the car." Mad?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, don't worry about it. It was just a travel dream.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I'm scared it means he's mad for real. Off wherever he's at.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He's not. He wouldn't. be mad. He's happy as a lark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sure! He's up there in some kind of motor heaven, polishing a car all his own. And it's always spring and the sun is always shining and there's always some blonde in a halter top to help him with the buffing.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You really think that might be true?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. Muriel looks at him lovingly. Really comforted. She reaches over and puts her hand on his. He seems about to move it, but then doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Macon, will you do this for me, will you just think about it tonight and decide in the morning? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Whether I can go with you tomorrow. _ I won't be any bother, I promise. Just think about it tonight, okay? After a long moment, he agrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is still dark out as Macon wakes and turns off his alarm. He lies there waking up, then remembers the bus- iness of the day. He seems to be mulling the Muriel issue with some odd good humor. He decides he will let her go with him. And he cannot suppress a smile as he sits up and reaches for the phone. He remembers the phone is out of order, but checks it at his ear for a moment anyway. He rises and pulls at the cord and leans over the bureau to peer down at where it is jacked to the wall. He puts the phone down and moves the heavy bureau a few inches away from the wall. He reacts to a twinge in his back, but shakes it off and stoops down toward the jack. There is a barely-audible little CRACK. And Macon freezes in his stooped position. His back has gone out, but he doesn't want to believe it. And if he doesn't move he won't be sure. After several moments of delay, he slowly straightens. The pain zings into him. He is barely able to make his way back to the bed and lower himself inch by inch onto it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Macon is asleep in exactly the same position. There is a KNOCK at the door. Macon opens his eyes. MURIEL 0O.S. Macon?...Macon, you in there? CLOSE ON Macon's eyes, as he makes a decision. A more rational decision. Informed by the sobering clarity of his current pain. He says nothing and listens and Muriel walks away. He closes his eyes again.  173 174 175 ; 129.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. The door to the room opens with the JINGLE of keys and a sweet, pale CHAMBERMAID pokes her head in. She sees Macon and begins to withdraw --

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERMAID
dialogues.text: Pardon, monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (raises his hand) No, wait!-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is on the phone at Julian's desk, which has been straightened up and cleared to an extreme degree.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Businessman's Press.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Um. This is Macon Leary. To whom am I --

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON _
dialogues.text: Rose?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes, it's me.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What are you doing there?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I work here now. .I'm putting things in order. You wouldn't believe the state this place is in.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Rose, my back has gone out on me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 175“ CONTINUED: : 175

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh, no, of all times! Are you still in Paris? :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I was just about to start my day trips and there are all these plans I have to change and no telephone in my room. So I was wondering: ..

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I'll take care of everything. Don't you bother with a thing. Have you seen a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Doctors don't help. Just bed rest.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, rest then, Macon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon is hunched in an armchair drinking wine which he pours from a small, mini-bar sized bottle. He is about to pour the last bit into his glass when there is a KNOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon?...Macon? Macon freezes, silent.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Darn it! Why did he go without me? : (moving away in the hall) Macon, you don't know what's good for you... He strains to listen, but she is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Macon is back in bed with his head propped just enough to watch the TV which is playing softly. Again there is a KNOCK. Macon does nothing. Then a key turns in the door and in walks Sarah, in a beige suit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hello, Macon! She smiles and comes over to kiss him. The Bellhop comes in after her with two pieces of matched luggage. She goes over to tip. and dismiss him in a breeze of brisk efficiency.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Now, everything's taken care of. I'm going to make your day trips for you. We've rescheduled the other cities and I start on them tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: But how did you get here so soon?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Rose is just a wizard. She's revamped that entire office. Here's a pill from Dr. Levitt. She pours some bottled water into a glass.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You know I don't take pills.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: This time you do. You're going to sleep as much as you can, so your back has a chance to heal. Swallow. Macon swallows the pill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Macon wakes up to find Sarah standing over him with a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Here's your next pill. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Those things are deadly. They knock me out. She sits down on the edge of the mattress, careful not to jar him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Macon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Hon.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I saw that woman friend of yours. Macon tenses. His back seizes up.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: She saw me, too. She seemed very surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sarah, this is not the way it looks.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (evenly) What is it then, Macon? I'd like to hear.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: She came over on her own. I didn't even know till just before the plane took off, I swear it! She followed me. I told her I didn't want her along. I told her it was no use.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You didn't know till just before the plane took off?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I swear it. (he looks at her) Do you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yes, I believe you. Macon holds her gaze for a moment, but then his eyelids slowly fall.  THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 133.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. Sarah bustles into the room with a bag of groceries, Macon is awake, having propped himself against a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I thought I'd make you supper myself. Fresh fruit and things.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: That's very nice of you, Sarah. Sarah begins unwrapping cheeses.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I was thinking, after I've finished the trips, if your back is better, maybe we could do a little sightseeing on our own.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Have a second honeymoon, sort of. He watches her set the cheeses on a flattened paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We'll change your plane ticket for a later date. You're reserved to leave tomorrow morning. No chance you could manage that. Did I tell you about Julian?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, what?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: He's moved in with Rose and your brothers.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: He's what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, Porter and Charles sit playing Vaccination. The * fourth seat, Macon's place, is now held down by -- Julian ‘SARAH (VO) * He lives there. He's started * playing Vaccination every night ; after supper. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wee we eet ee THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 134.

dialogues.speaker: MACON, (VO)
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be damned. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah passes Macon a glass. * SARAH . Apple cider. A toast to our second * honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Our second honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Eighteen more years together. *

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Eighteen. *

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Or would you say seventeen? *

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, it's eighteen, all right. *

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I mean because we skipped this past year.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh. No, it would still be eighteen. *

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I consider this last year just another stage in our marriage. ‘ Don't worry, it's eighteen. Sarah clinks her*glass against his. She begins to cut a peach into sections and passes him one of the sections.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Macon. Just tell me this. Was the little boy the attraction?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Was the fact that she had a child what attracted you to that woman? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17983 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 135.

dialogues.speaker: MACUN
dialogues.text: Sarah, I swear to you, I had no idea she was planning to follow me over here.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yes, I realize that, but I was wondering about the child question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What child question?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I was remembering the time you said we should have another baby.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Oh, well, that was just... I don't know what that was. He hands her back the peach; he isn't hungry anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I was thinking maybe you were right.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What? (understands ) No, Sarah. Lord, that was a terrible idea.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh, I know it's scary. I admit I'd be scared to have another.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Exactly. We're too old.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No, I'm talking about the, you know, world we'd be bringing him into. So much evil and danger. I admit it, I'd be frantic any time we let him out on the street.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes, there's that. They are silent for a few moments. Macon is thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Though really it's kind of... heartening, isn’t it? How most human beings do try. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 136. 179B CONTINUED: . r (2) 1798 *

dialogues.speaker: MACON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How they try to be as responsible and kind as they can manage.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Are you saying, yes, we can have a baby?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, no. It seems to me we're past the time for that, Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So, her little boy wasn't the reason. He looks at her sharply, his tone a little harsh.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: What are we talking about here, Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (voice rising) Can't you just answer me? I want a to understand.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Look, it's over with. Can't we close the lid on it? I don't cross-examine you, do I?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: But I don't have someone following me to Paris!

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: And what if you did? Would I blame you if someone just climbed on a plane without your knowing?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Before it left the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Pardon? What? Sarah!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Before it left the ground, you saw her. You could have walked up to her and said, "No. Get off. Go e this minute. I want nothing more : to do with you and I never want to see you again." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1798 180 181 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 137.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You think I own the airline,. Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You could have stopped her if you'd really wanted. You could have taken steps. They fall silent. Sarah rises and begins clearing away their supper. Macon watches her move around the room. It's hard to tell if the pain in his eyes is coming from his back or something less physical. Sarah opens a pill bottle, shakes a white pill into her palm and brings it to Macon. Her eyes barely meet his as she hands him the sleeping pill and turns away. Macon closes his fist around the pill and lets it rest on the blanket. Sarah goes into the bathroom. She is upset. When she catches sight of herself in the mirror, she is startled and a little embarrassed. She sees Macon's reflection in the mirror watching her and, almost reflexively, pushes the bathroom door halfway closed to obliterate his view. Macon slowly lowers himself down into the bed, and suddenly the CAMERA is CLOSE ON him in_exactly the same i i i at the start of their affair. And like then, Macon lies in bed and HEARS: Sarah running water in the bathroom, moving about the room as she gets undressed and hangs her clothes, the TINKLING of the chain as she slips it on the door, the SWITCHING OFF of the lights. The bed moves and Macon's back stabs pain as Sarah slips in beside him, but he makes no sound. He listens te Sarah's breathing as it softens almost immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE-UP on Macon's hand as it slowly opens and he lets the white pill fall among the bedclothes.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Macon's face. He turns to look beside him. DISSOLVE TO: Sarah's face, in profile, from Macon's POV. She is sleep- ing. DISSOLVE TO: THE REVERSE SHOT -- Sarah sleeping in the foreground, Macon looking at her. A long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon, hunched and pained, comes into the bathroom. He slowly-- every move is slow -- begins to shave.  182 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 138.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon, dressed now, is slowly packing his things into his bag. He takes the framed photo of Ethan from the bureau and slips it into the outer pocket of the bag. Each movement is laborious. The last item is his heavy book, Miss MacIntosh, My Darling. He puts it into his bag, newly impressed with its weight. He thinks about it, then takes it out of the bag and sets it aside on the bureau. He will leave it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Macon? He turns to look at her in bed.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Sarah. I'm glad you're awake.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I'm packing to leave. She sits up. Her face is creased down one side.

dialogues.speaker: SARAR
dialogues.text: But what about your back? And I've got all those appointments! We were going to take a second honeymoon. ‘ MACON Sweetheart. Macon makes his way over to her and lowers himself cautiously till he is sitting on the bed. He picks up her hand -- it stays lifeless while she watches his face.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You're going back to that woman.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Why, Macon?

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I just decided, Sarah. I thought about it most of last night. It wasn't easy. It's not the easy way out, believe me. She stares at him, with no expression. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 182 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST - Rev. 12/14/87 139.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to miss the plane. He inches to a standing position and hobbles into the bathroom for his shaving kit.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You know what this is? It's all due to that pill! You said yourself it knocks you out. Now it's messed up your thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I didn't take the pill. There is a silence.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Macon? Are you just trying to get even with me for the time I left you? Macon returns with the shaving kit.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: No, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I suppose you realize what your life is going to be like. She climbs out of bed and comes over to stand next to him in her nightgown, hugging her bare arms.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (without heat) You'll be one of those mismatched couples no one invites to parties. No one will know what to make of you. People will wonder whenever they meet you, "My God, what does be see in her? Why choose someone so inappropriate?" And her friends will be asking the same thing about you.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: You're probably right. He zips his overnight bag. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sarah. I didn't want to decide this. It's silly to even think we know what's going to happen. Maybe this is just another stage in our marriage. And not the last. Macon puts his arm around her painfully, and, after a pause, she lets her‘head rest against his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (very calm) I thought this might happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macon manages the front door by backing through it, stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No taxis in sight. He sets off for the next block. Car- rying his bag is torture. He tries it in his left hand, then his right. He steps over to a building with a low stone curb running around its base. He sets the bag on the curb, takes out Ethan's picture, leaves the bag, and hurries on. Up ahead he sees a taxi with a boy just step- ping out of it. Raising either arm is impossible. He is forced to run in an absurd, scuttling fashion while shouting bits of French.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Attendez! Attendez, monsieur! The taxi is already moving off and the Boy is just slip- ping his wallet back into his jeans when he sees Macon and calls out something and the taxi brakes. Macon makes his way up to the cab, panting.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: (to the Boy) Merci beaucoup. The Boy, who has a sweet, pure face and shaggy yellow hai opens the taxi door for him and gently assists him in.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 185
dialogues.text: The Boy shuts the door and then, to Macon's surprise, i . The taxi moves off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Taxi Driver looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Charles De Gaulle Airport. The Driver makes a U-turn, heading back in the direction Macon has just come from. They pass the Boy once again, walking along the sidewalk. . Macon leans forward to peer intently at him, blinking to clear his view. MACON MOVING POV of the French Boy as the taxi passes. His face is not so very different than Ethan's would have been, these two years later...if Ethan had lived. Macon sits back, but he does not look sad. In fact, there is some kind of peace in the memory and the forward movement of the Boy and the taxi. The taxi approaches Macon's hotel. A Man is just emerg- ing with a small anxious dog on his arm. And there on the curb stands Muriel, surrounded by suit- cases and string-handled shopping bags and cardboard cartons overflowing with red velvet. She is frantically waving down taxis -- first one ahead, then Macon's own.

dialogues.speaker: MACON
dialogues.text: Arretez!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi lurches to a halt. Muriel looks surprised by its sudden stop. She smiles for a moment at the Driver and her eyes sweep over Macon -- not registering him -- as she turns to begin collecting her bags. Macon watches, suspended in the moment, with a kind of joy. Suddenly, Muriel's mind registers what she has glimpsed in the shadowy back seat. She straightens and turns, very slowly it seems to Macon. And now a much larger smile lights her face. Her gaze locks directly onto his -- and where they meet, there is a blinding, white burst of light.
